https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26223545/

 

 

CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIA – HOW YOU CAN HELP?

You can simulate the dynamics of COVID-19 proteins to hunt for new therapeutic opportunities

2019-nCoV behaves in a similar way and it is very similar to SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV). For both coronaviruses, mostly the first step of infection takes place in the lungs, when a protein on the area of the virus binds  to a receptor protein on a lung cell. The name of this viral protein is spike protein, present in red on the image below, and the receptor is known as ACE2. There is known one kind of protein – therapeutic antibody, it has the possibility to block the viral protein from binding to its receptor, and also can stop the virus from infecting the lung cell. There is already developed therapeutic antibody for SARS-, but to develop small molecules or  therapeutic antibodies for 2019-nCoV, researchers need to better know the structure of the viral spike protein and how it binds to the human ACE2 receptor required for viral entry into human cells.

Proteins are not stagnant—they wiggle and fold and unfold to take on numerous shapes.  We need to study not only one shape of the viral spike protein, but all the ways the protein wiggles and folds into alternative shapes in order to best understand how it interacts with the ACE2 receptor, so that an antibody can be designed. Low-resolution structures of the SARS-CoV spike protein exist and we know the mutations that differ between SARS-CoV and 2019-nCoV.  Given this information, we are uniquely positioned to help model the structure of the 2019-nCoV spike protein and identify sites that can be targeted by a therapeutic antibody. We can build computational models that accomplish this goal, but it takes a lot of computing power.   

This is where you can contribute! With many computers working towards the same goal, we aim to help develop a therapeutic remedy as quickly as possible. Being part of Corona@Home, you can help provide us with the computational power required to tackle this problem. One protein from 2019-nCoV, a protease encoded by the viral RNA, has already been crystallized. Although the 2019-nCoV spike protein of interest has not yet been resolved bound to ACE2, our objective is to use the homologous structure of the SARS-CoV spike protein to identify therapeutic antibody targets.

We can benefit from supercomputing power, scientific software framework and improved protein structure prediction using potentials from deep learning as a part of machine learning (see the section: DEEP LEARNING – IMPROVE PROTEIN STRUCTURE PREDICTION).

COVID-19 research currently in development

Corona@home is in contact with medical research organizations to provide them computing and deep learning power, to expedite the discovery and rollout of tests, treatments and cures.

According to The Milken Institute, who created aggregation of publicly available information from validated sources, we track a comprehensive online tracker (https://milkeninstitute.org/sites/default/files/2020-03/Covid19%20Tracker%20032020v3-posting.pdf)  that looks at all of the COVID-19 research currently in development. Each row tracks a treatment or vaccine from discovery to clinical trial, accompanied by the name of the organization undertaking the research. This tool, collated from publicly available sources, will be updated regularly and we’ll contact listed institutions with a proposal of cooperation.

The essential component for many biological functions is protein. It takes actions in biological functions and participates in virtually all processes within biological cells. Commonly they behave like enzymes, carrying out biochemical reactions including cell signaling, cellular regulation and molecular transportation. Some act as a type of antibodies, others as a skeleton for cells and some proteins participate in the immune system.

 

 

In the picture, we can see proteins on cancer cells, and joining it antibody. Source:https://d4j2i6ubvolvu.cloudfront.net/sites/defa...

First, before protein is allowed to take these roles, it must fold into a functional three-dimensional structure. This process is mostly spontaneous and depends on interaction within its amino acid sequence and interactions of the amino acids with their area.

Its very important to understanding how protein works and behave, and it is recognized as a holy grail of computational biology. Usually when in a crowded cellular environment folding is happening, the process passes smoothly. But, when due to a protein’s chemical characteristic or other factors, proteins can misfold. It means when protein fold down in the wrong way and end up deformed. If cellular mechanisms do not have the ability to refold misfolded proteins or destroy them, then they can aggregate and cause different diseases.

Because of complicatication of proteins conformation and also configuration space, and limits of computing power., stimulation of all-atom molecular dynamics have been very limited in the timescale.

Most proteins before 2010 mostly fold in the order of milliseconds, and simulation could only be done nanosecond to microsecond timescales. Power of supercomputers of usually have been used for simulating protein folding. But this operation was very expensive and mostly only shared among many research groups. Protein folding is not one step process. In some cases folding time of protein is nearly 96%, waiting in various intermediate conformational states, each a local thermodynamic free energy minimum in the protein’s energy landscape.

Folding@home is using conformations of a process known as adaptive sampling, and it is their starting point for a set of simulation trajectories. With every discovery of conformations made by simulations, trajectories are restarted from them and from this process is slowly created the Markov state model (MSM).

The length of the proteins that has studied Folding@home during 2000 and 2010 have increased by a factor of four, while its timescale of protein folding have increased by six orders of magnitude. Folding@home in 2002 started to use Markov state models to gather approximately a million CPU days of simulation over the span of a few months.

MSMs correlated another simulation in 2011 that required an aggregate of 10 million CPU hours of computing. Folding@home used MSMs in January 2010, to simulate the dynamics of the slow-folding 32-residue NTL9 protein out to 1.52 milliseconds, it was timescale compatible with experimental folding rate predictions. But it was a thousand times longer than achieved in the first place. Model was built with individual trajectories, each two orders of magnitude shorter, this was providing an unparalleled level of many details into the protein’s energy area.

WHAT IS PROTEIN FOLDING

Protein folding it is a physical process consisting of formation by a polypeptide (it owns a structure of random coil) highly organized structure with a characteristic and stable conformation.

Each protein is assumed to be in the form of an unstructured polypeptide chain shortly after translation. Such a polypeptide does not show the presence of a well-defined, stable spatial structure. It is only due to the interaction between adjacent amino acids that the polypeptide begins to adopt a specific conformation, often referred to as the “native” state. It is currently believed that the main factor determining the native structure of a given protein is its amino acid sequence, however, some observations indicate that the natural structure of proteins found in a living cell may be dependent on interactions with other proteins or nucleic acids.

 

For most known proteins, the correct spatial structure is necessary for their physiological role. Failure to adopt the expected structure usually leads to the formation of a protein with different properties that can even be toxic to the body (an example can be many prion proteins). Much evidence suggests that certain neurodegenerative diseases are caused by the accumulation of proteins with abnormal structures such as amyloids that form long fibers in the cells.

References:

Berg JM, Tymoczko JL, Stryer L (2002). “3. Protein Structure and Function”. Biochemistry. San Francisco: W. H. Freeman. ISBN 978-0-7167-4684-3.

Dennis J. Selkoe. Folding proteins in fatal ways. „Nature”, s. 900–904, 2003. DOI: 10.1038/nature02264. PMID: 14685251.

The Shape and Structure of Proteins. W: Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, and Peter Walters: Molecular Biology of the Cell; Fourth Edition. Garland Science, 2002. ISBN 0-8153-3218-1.

 

EXAMPLES OF APPLICATION IN BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH

Protein misfolding can cause different diseases, for example Huntington’s disease, sickle-cell anemia, cancer, Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, Alzheimer’s disease and also type II diabetes. Virus HIV and also Influenza cause cellular infection are implay folding events on cell membranes. Understanding better protein misfolding, treatments can compound  that boost cells native ability to control protein folding. 

 

 

 

 

Such therapies include the use of engineered molecules to alter the production of a given protein, and help to destroy a misfolded protein, or assist in the folding process. The combination of computational molecular modeling and experimental analysis has the possibility to fundamentally shape the future of molecular medicine and the rational design of therapeutics. such as expediting and lowering the costs of drug discovery. For example, the first five years of work at Folding@home  was focused on progression in understanding folding, when now the goal is to understand misfolding and related disease, especially Alzheimer’s.

 

 

The simulations created by Folding@home are used in connection with experiments in the laboratory, but research workers   can use them to study how folding in vitro differs from folding in native cellular environments. Studying aspects of misfolding, folding and also correlations with diseases is really advantageous. For example, in 2011 Folding@home lead simulated protein folding inside a ribosomal exit which occurred to help researchers understand how natural confinement and crowding might influence the folding process. 

 

 

Typically, scientists use a chemical compound – denatured alcoholin research to unfold proteins from their stable native state, but in general there  is no knowledge how it can affect the protein refolding. Folding@home in 2010 used GPUs to simulate the unfolded states of Protein L, and predicted its collapse rate in strong agreement with experimental results.

 

 

Non-profit unit – The Pande Lab which is part of Stanford University. Results of big data from projects are available for free. It can be used by other researchers upon request and also some of it can be obtained from Folding@home.

 

 

The collaborations between Blue Gene supercomputer, and Pande Lab and they ahre Folding@home key software with different research workers and various science centers. Thanks to that, algorithms which were useful for Folding@home, can be fruitful in other scientific areas. 

 

 

The open-source Copernicus software, which they released in 2011 is based on Folding@home’s MSM and other parallelizing techniques and its target is to improve the efficiency and scaling of molecular simulations on large computer clusters or supercomputers. All summaries of every scientific discovery from Folding@home are available on Folding@home website.

 

References:

HIDDEN MARKOV MODEL

 

Corona@home uses Markov state models, like the one diagrammed here, to model the possible shapes and folding pathways a protein can take as it condenses from its initial randomly coiled state (left) into its native 3-D structure (right).

A protein before and after folding. It starts in an unstable random coil state and finishes in its native state conformation.

 

 

DEEP LEARNING – improve protein structure prediction

machine learning, artificial intelligence to improve protein structure prediction associated with COVID-19

Predicting the protein structure can be used to make a three-dimensional shape of a protein which is based on its amino acid sequence. This is the biggest dilmate for researchers, because the structure of protein in a big group regulate its function, but still structures of protein can be very hard to set experimentally. The last major progression of these studies has been achieved through the use of genetic information. We can predict which of the amino  acid remains are in interconnection. This can be reached by analyzing covariance in homologous sequences, which helps in predicting given protein structures.It gave us the chance to teach a neural network. Thanks to that, we have the ability to make accurate good forecasting of the distances between pairs of residues. This date includes much more information about structure than contact predictions. Applying this information, we have the ability to formulate a potential of power that can precisely portray the shape of a protein. This potential  we can form by a simple gradient descent algorithm to bring out structures without complex sampling procedures. 

By uncovering the prognosis of the structure of several poorly studied proteins related with  SARs-Cov_2- the virus that causes COVID-19, we can contribute to the development of science associated with this. We point, that these projections have not been scientifically confirmed. But we hope that they may do something for science associated with viruses functions and help with making hypothesis generation platform for future experimental work in developing therapeutics. 

For half a century  research workers had the ability to specify patterns of proteins in laboratories using magnetic resonance and X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy and also nuclear magnetic resonance. But error and trials  appear in each of these methods, and costs tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars per each protein structure and also it can take many years of research. That is why AI methods are chosen by biologists as a shorter path for  process for difficult proteins. They have two options. In the first they work on genetic code and thanks to this can predict the shape of the protein – faster and more reliable method. The second option available is to determine the protein with the help of long and costly experiments.

How can AI make a difference?


Thanks to rapid reduction in the cost of genetic sequencing the field of genomics is much more rich in data.The effect shows in deep  learning and it approaches the prediction problem that rely on genomic data have become increasingly successful in the last years. Biennial global competition called the Critical Assessment of Techniques for Protein Structure Prediction (CASP) was established in 1994. The CASP has been created to accumulate measure and research progress on the newest methods to accomplish better accuracy of predictions .

 

In the center of interest for  AI teams is mainly the problem of modeling target shapes from zero, and without using previously solved proteins as patterns. AI teams  gained a high degree of precision, during predicting the physical properties of a protein structure, and then used two separate methods to create predictions of full protein structures. 

Using neural networks to predict physical properties

Deep neural networks that are trained to predict properties of the protein form its genetic sequence – these two methods are based on this. The properties networks predict are: (a) the distances between pairs of amino acids and (b) the angles between chemical bonds that connect those amino acids.

 The first development is a progression of generally used techniques that estimate whether pairs of amino acids are near each other. A skilled neural network can predict a distribution of distances between every pair of residues in a protein (visualised in Figure 2). These probabilities were then combined into a score that estimates how accurate a proposed protein structure is. We can also train a single neural network that uses all distances in aggregate to estimate how close the proposed structure is to the right answer.

FIGURE 2: Two ways of visualising the accuracy of prediction. The top figure features the distance matrices for three proteins. The brightness of each pixel represents the distance between the amino acids in the sequence comprising the protein – the brighter pixel, the closer the pair. Shown in the top row are the real, experimentally determined distances and, in the bottom row, the average predicted distances distributions. Importantly, these match well on both global and local scales. The bottom panels represent the same comparison using 3d models, featuring predictions (blue) versus ground-truth data (green) for the same three proteins. 

Because of the ability to use  these scoring functions, we can look for protein shape  and try to find structures that match our predictions. 

In the first method, which  is built on techniques usually used in structural biology, and repeatedly substituted parts of a protein structure with new protein fragments. Trained a generative neural network to invent novel  parts, which are used to incessantly develop the score of the proposed protein structure.

FIGURE 3: A schematic of the architecture of the ALPHAFOLD system predicting structure from protein sequence. 

 

The second method optimised scores through gradient descent—a mathematical technique mostly  used in machine learning for making small, incremental improvements—which appear in highly precise structures. This technique was applied to entire protein chains rather than to pieces that must be folded separately before being built up into a bigger structure, to simplify the prediction process.

We are amazed  by the prosperity of the protein folding model, but still there is a lot of work before us in the realm of protein biology. We really want to find a way to establishing methods that AI can cooperate to fundamental scientific discovery.

Because of that kind of thinking, it will lead us in the end to improve understanding about how it works and will be helpful for scientists to target and construct new, effective treatments for diseases in an improved way. Scientists have only mapped structures for about half of all the proteins made by human cells. There are a lot of rare diseases with mutation in a single gene, and this results in a malformed protein which can have  intense outcome on the health of an entire organism. 

This method probably has the ability to help us and reachers workers to find efficient drug discovery, and during this reducing the costs associated with experimentation. In our hearts, we hope that thanks to using AI for disease research could be useful and helpful to improve quality of life for millions of patients all over the globe. But advantages from it are not only restricted for health issues. Great knowledge about protein folding can also be of some use for instance  in advances in biodegradable enzymes – this can be done by protein design. This research could help us manage pollutants like oil and plastic, and support us in breaking down waste in ways that are more friendly to our earth. Some scientists have already begun engineering bacteria to single proteins that will make waste biodegradable and much more easier to process. Machine learning systems can integrate various sources of information about protein folding  – this significant data can help scientists come up with solutions to complex problems in a faster way. As we know how AI can help people master complex games through systems like AlphaGo and AlphaZero, We think AI breakthroughs will help serve as a platform to advance our knowledge of essential, scientific dilemmas in a much quicker way. 

It is very interesting and exciting to be witness  to these signs of progress in protein folding, improving the utility of AI for scientific discovery. There is still numerous work and a lot of  research to do before we are able to have a significant effect on treating diseases, managing waste, and more and more… and we know the potential of it is  tremendous.

Jones, D. T. & Kandathil, S. M. High precision in protein contact prediction using fully convolutional neural networks and minimal sequence features. Bioinformatics 34, 3308–3315 (2018).

Xu, J. & Wang, S. Analysis of distance-based protein structure prediction by deep learning in CASP13. Proteins 87, 1069–1081 (2019).

Li, Y., Zhang, C., Bell, E. W., Yu, D.-J. & Zhang, Y. Ensembling multiple raw coevolutionary features with deep residual neural networks for contact-map prediction in CASP13. Proteins 87, 1082–1091 (2019).

 

Corona@home’s DEV and system architecture

 

Corona@home system involves five components: work units, core, server/grid of the masternodes, client/wallet and tools (client for mobile phones and nextgen video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft planned in the future)

Work units

A work unit is the protein data that the client is asked to process. Work units are a fraction of the simulation between the states in a Markov state model. After the work unit has been downloaded and fully processed by a users computer, it is returned to Corona@home servers, which then award the user with  credit points and this cycle is automatic. All work units have linked deadlines, and if this deadline is exceeded, the user may not get credit and the unit will be automatically reissued to another participant. As protein folding occurs serially, and many work units are generated from their predecessors, this gives  the overall simulation process to proceed in a normal way if a work unit is not returned after a sensible period of time. Because of these deadlines  the minimum system demand for Corona@home is a Pentium 3 450 MHz CPU with Streaming SIMD Extensions (SSE). Major advantage of the scientific benefit is dependent on rapidly competing simulations that’s why work units for high-performance clients have a  much shorter deadline than those for the uniprocessor client.

Before public release, work units go through several quality assurance steps to keep problematic ones from becoming fully available. These testing stages include internal, beta, and advanced, before a final full release across Corona@home. Work units from Corona@home’s are typically processed only once, except in the uncommon event that errors occur during processing. If this occurs for three different users, the unit is automatically pulled from distribution.The Corona@home support forum can be used to differentiate between issues arising from problematic hardware and bad work units.

Core

The calculations on the work unit are made by specialized molecular dynamics programs as a background process.  Major amount of Corona@home’s cores are lean on GROMACS(GROningen MAchine for Chemical Simulations). It is one of the powerful and most popular molecular dynamics software packages, which mostly rely on manually optimized assembly language code and hardware optimizations.To enable the scientific methods to be updated automatically without requiring a client update the core is separated from the clienti. When work of cores is interrupted can resume work from  point upon startup that is why cores periodically create calculation checkpoints. GROMACS is a comprehensive package to perform molecular dynamics, i.e. simulate the Newtonian equations of motion for systems with hundreds to millions of particles.

It is  mostly designed for biochemical molecules like proteins, lipids and nucleic acids that have a lot of complicated bonded interactions, but since GROMACS is very fast at calculating the nonbonded interactions many groups are also using it for research on non-biological systems, e.g. polymers.

GROMACS assists  all the standard algorithms you expect from modern molecular dynamics implementation.  In the code a lot of algorithmic optimizations have been introduced. For example, extract the calculation of the virial from the innermost loops over pairwise interactions, and they use their own software routines to calculate the inverse square root.

In GROMACS 4.6 and up, on almost all common computing platforms, the innermost loops are written in C using inner  functions that the compiler transforms to SIMD machine instructions, to utilize the accessible instruction-level parallelism. These kernels are available in  single and also double precision, and assist all the different kinds of SIMD support found in x86-family processors.

http://www.gromacs.org

Client/Wallet

Users of Corona@home install a client/wallet program on their  personal computer (mobile devices and next gen game consoles – future roadmap). Participant collaborate with the client, which manages other software or masternodes components in the background.Throughout the client/wallet, the user may stop and pause the folding process, open an event log, and check work development  or also view personal statistics. Computers of clients run uninterruptedly in the background at a low priority, by using idle processing power and because of that clients computer normal work is unaffected. The maximum CPU use can be adjusted via client settings.The client connects to a Corona@home server and retrieves a work unit and may also download the appropriate core for the client’s settings, operating system, and the underlying hardware architecture. After processing, the work unit is returned to the Corona@home servers. 

Computer clients are conformable to uniprocessors and multi-core processor systems, and also graphics processing units. The diversity and power of each hardware architecture provides Corona@home with the ability to successfully complete many types of simulations in a timely manner (in a few weeks or months rather than years), which is of significant scientific value. Together, these clients allow researchers to study biomedical questions formerly considered impractical to tackle computationally.

Professional software developers are responsible for Corona@home’s code, both for the client and server-side.  While the client’s graphical user interface (GUI) is open-source, the client is proprietary software citing security and scientific integrity as the reasons. 

CLIENT/WALLET FOR MOBILE PHONES ( ROADMAP Q3 2020)

1. Monitor the progress and status of your folding slots while not being near your systems. It will also enable you to change settings of the configuration of your folding systems or visualize proteins in 3D on your computer or servers which they work on.

2. Due to the progressively increasing performance of top smartphones (e.g based on Snapdragon 865 with Adreno 650 GPU or Apple A13 Bionic with A13 Bionic’s GPU), we plan to include Android and iOS apps and implement mobile devices in the Corona@home’s distributed computing ecosystem.

SERVER / MASTERNODE

Masternodes serve as the integrity of Corona@home’s blockchain ecosystem, stakeable CORO passive income and a grid of distributed supercomputers to simulate and predict the dynamics of proteins.

For volunteering and network grid using API, an open-source middleware system  is anticipated – Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing (BOINC).

At first it was used to support the SETI@home, but this platform became resultful in a novel and inventive way for other applications in  various fields of science like mathematics, medicine, molecular biology, climatology, astrophysics, linguistics. The target of BOINC is to provide researchers to step into the enormous processing resources of multiple personal computers around the world.

Scientific computations are run on users’ computers. After sending the user from the client to the scientific researchers database, the backend server checks and analyzes the results. The validation process engage  running all tasks on computers with multiple collaborators and comparing results.  

BOINC provides APIs for various types of applications and web sites that interact with BOINC components:

  • Client GUIs: Applications that control local or remote BOINC clients.
  • Credit statistics web sites: Web sites showing credit information (project totals, user/team/country leaderboards) based on daily XML feeds of statistics data from BOINC projects. The XML format is documented here.
  • Account managers: Web sites that let BOINC users create and manage accounts on multiple projects.
  • Aggregate credit statistics: Web RPCs for getting cross-project credit data for hosts, teams and users.
  • Web RPCs: These interfaces let a program or web site obtain information about projects, and create/edit entities (users, teams, hosts) on projects.
  • Local editing of preferences: This mechanism lets you write programs for local editing of preferences.
  • APIs for remote job submission, management of input files, and fetching output files.

https://boinc.berkeley.edu

TOOLS

Biopython – set of tools for biological computation written in Python by an international team of developers

TensorFlow – machine learning models for desktop, mobile, web, and cloud. 

Open Neural Network Exchange(ONNX) – open standard for machine learning interoperability

Uniclust – Databases of clustered and deeply annotated protein sequences and alignments

HHpred web server – Bioinformatics Toolkit

CATH – database, online resource that provides information on the evolutionary relationships of protein domains

PDB – Protein Data Bank archive, repository of information about the 3D structures of proteins, nucleic acids, and complex assemblies.

SST (web server): Secondary STructure assignment to protein coordinate data using the Bayesian method of Minimum Message Length inference

TM-align – an algorithm for sequence independent protein structure comparisons. For two protein structures of unknown equivalence, TM-align first generates optimized residue-to-residue alignment based on structural similarity using heuristic dynamic programming iterations

Microsoft Cognitive Toolkit – deep learning framework

CMView – Protein contact map visualization and analysis with PyMOL molecular visualization system

 

Roadmap

 

Q1.2020

Research & Development

Mainnet Preparation

Launch public testnet V1.0

Preparation of the CORO technical support

Open mainnet masternode feature

CORO Network Mainnet release

Desktop wallets for Windows, Linux and OSX

 

Q2.2020

Proof of concept

Update of CORO's purchase portfolio

Moves to public repository

Deep learning algorithms with masternodes integration

Blockchain wallets for distributed computing integration

Tools and core implementation to performing molecular dynamics simulations

Computing power available for scientific institutions and researches

 

Q3.2020

Computing & researches

BOINC client/server and API integration

CPU and GPU accelerated computing for scientific institutions and researches

Mobile apps development (control folding server and mobile wallets)

On-line wallet (an option)

CORO debut on selected crypto exchanges

 

Q4.2020

Productivity expansion

Energy efficiency and productivity for precise targeted AI projects

Launch CORO white label trading platform with major currency pairs
Ledger hardware wallet integration

Client development for Sony Playstation 5 and Microsoft XBOX Series X

 

2021

Global market expansion

Centre for Distributed and Global Computing Projects

 

 

ExecutiveTeam

Meet the people behind

 

Daniel Możdżyński

Project Manager,
Co-founder

He completed PhD studies at the Faculty of Informatics and e-Economy, Department of Information Technology at the Poznan University of Economics and Business and post-graduate studies - "IT Project Management". He is a graduate of the MBA at the WSB University in Poznan in cooperation with the Franklin University in Ohio. He gained professional experience and expert knowledge in such companies as HP, Fujitsu-Siemens, General Electric and at leading integrators of ICT solutions. He belongs to the Agile Alliance and PMI (Project Management Institute), where he has the status of a member. The author of academic publications, agile coach, mentor, lecturer and an experienced project practitioner

 

Tomasz Węgliński

Developer, Co-founder

Full Stack Blockchain Developer. Highly professional blockchain developer with 15 years of experience, solid leadership skills, and unrivalled building skills. Experienced in languages such as Python, Perl, C/C++, PowerShell. Data Science skills - Python, R and Data Analytics/Machine Learning skills

 

Krzysztof Wójcicki

PhD in the field of Commodity Science, from PUEB. He works at the Department of Technology and Instrumental Analysis at the Institute of Quality Science, PUEB. His work center around the novel methods for quality evaluation of various food and non-food products. He is particularly interested in the field of spectroscopy and multivariate data analysis.

 

Elżbieta Wanowska

Magda Krzciuk

Administrative Specialist, Customer Service

She provides administrative and customer support to the Corona@home. She has experience providing administrative support in both corporate and non-profit settings. Her fields of interest are financial market and foreign-exchange market, which is her job for almost four years. She also actively participates in cryptocurrency market
story_txt:
WHAT IS THE PROJECT ABOUT?Corona@home is the first blockchain and deep learning based, distributed masternode computing project for performing molecular dynamics simulations of protein dynamics. The leading focus is on fighting SARS-CoV-2 and all the new viruses in the future, by joining research workers around the world for understanding better the 2019 Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), to accelerate the open science effort to develop new life-saving therapies.It’s giving us the possibility for simulating protein dynamics, how the coronavirus proteins work, and how to develop therapeutics to stop them or treat.Our project partly derives from the idea that guided the creators of the long-running project SETI@home, which is unfortunately ending the volunteer program this month. It uses distributed computing to analyze radio telescope data in the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence. Clearly graphics cards are mainly intended for video editing, gaming and even mining of cryptocurrency. But not everyone knows that they can “donate” their AMD Radeon or Nvidia GPU’s spare compute cycles to analyze and possibly help to fight against the ongoing coronavirus pandemic?Software that we develop uses the spare CPU and GPU cycles of thousands of game consoles, smartphones and computers, globally to simulate computational antidote design and protein folding.Viruses include proteins that they use to repress human immune systems and multiply themselves. To follow coronavirus behavior, we want to comprehend how these viral proteins work and how we can invent therapeutics to cure it and eventually stop them.Corona@home can make use of computer simulations to recognize a protein’s moving parts. After that, scientists have a firm grasp on how the atoms move and cooperate within a protein, they can proceed much more closer to explore therapeutics to treat it.Simulations like that, demand massive computational power. And our project Corona@home can carry out compute power as possible at fighting SARS-CoV-2.Because of this networked supercomputer, research workers can project proteins at the level of individual atoms in a fraction of the time, it might take even one powerful computer. Many important biological processes that proteins perform take place over milliseconds to a few seconds. A lot of important biological processes that proteins carry out take places over milliseconds to a few seconds.That might seem short, but measuring atoms as they bounce off one another depends upon time scales in femtoseconds — one quadrillionth of a second.To model just one millisecond of folding, even average-size protein, on a top-of-the-line PC, it can take like 500 years, but thanks to the possibility of Corona@home, we can split these problems into many individual parts. At the same time we can send them for example to 1,000 people at the same time . Running those calculations in parallel, we can take these problems that would have taken 500 years and instead deal with them in months.Corona@home serves could be a starting point for new drug design.At this time, scientists often have only one well-known protein structure to analyze. For example, Beta lactamase is a protein that some bacteria deploy to conserve themselves from antibiotics like penicillin. The protein has a long-studied and well-documented structure. But this structure is only about a single snapshot of beta lactamase at one moment in time.That snapshot contains valuable information, but it’s kind of like seeing a picture of a construction vehicle in a parking lot and trying to guess what it does. Really, what you would like is to watch this thing move around and see how it works together with other machinery to, say, build a building. We’re interested in watching how every atom in a protein moves — as it’s being assembled for the first time and as it goes about its jobs. The atoms in a protein are never still, they’re constantly jostling and moving around. And one genetic mutation changes maybe a dozen atoms out of thousands. We want to understand what that does to the entire protein.For example examining the movement of beta lactamase, already has revealed “cryptic pockets,” Achilles heel in the protein that could be targeted by drugs but that are not visible in the long-studied snapshot of this protein. The cryptic pockets only reveal themselves when the protein is moving. Corona@home provide scientists a look at long-studied proteins, revealing solutions to biological problems that might be not seen in the first placeAs part of the client–server model network architecture, the volunteered machines each receive pieces of a simulation (work units), complete them, and return them to the project’s database servers, where the units are compiled into an overall simulation. Volunteers will track their contributions on the Corona@home website, which makes volunteers’ participation competitive and encourages long-term involvement.Laboratories around the world are generating in an unprecedented manner, more and more genome sequences and related clinical and epidemiological data associated with the newly emerging coronavirus (hCoV-19) rapidly made available via GISAID (https://www.gisaid.org), which enabled researchers to rapidly develop tests for this novel pathogen. Other labs have shared experimentally-determined and computationally-predicted structures of some of the viral proteins, and still others have shared epidemiological data. We can benefit from improved protein structure prediction using potentials from deep learning as a part of machine learning.Figure SARS-COV-2 membrane protein: a rendering of one of protein structure predictionsTo help us run scientific simulations is the primary way to contribute. These calculations are enormous and every little bit helps! Each simulation you run is like buying a lottery ticket. The more tickets we buy, the better our chances of hitting the jackpot. Usually, your computer or server will never be idle. There is a lot of valuable science to be done, and we’re getting it running as quickly as we can.Source: Corona@home’s team. CMView – Protein contact map visualization and analysis with PyMOL molecular visualization system

CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIA – HOW YOU CAN HELP?
You can simulate the dynamics of COVID-19 proteins to hunt for new therapeutic opportunities2019-nCoV behaves in a similar way and it is very similar to SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV). For both coronaviruses, mostly the first step of infection takes place in the lungs, when a protein on the area of the virus binds  to a receptor protein on a lung cell. The name of this viral protein is spike protein, present in red on the image below, and the receptor is known as ACE2. There is known one kind of protein – therapeutic antibody, it has the possibility to block the viral protein from binding to its receptor, and also can stop the virus from infecting the lung cell. There is already developed therapeutic antibody for SARS-, but to develop small molecules or  therapeutic antibodies for 2019-nCoV, researchers need to better know the structure of the viral spike protein and how it binds to the human ACE2 receptor required for viral entry into human cells.Proteins are not stagnant—they wiggle and fold and unfold to take on numerous shapes.  We need to study not only one shape of the viral spike protein, but all the ways the protein wiggles and folds into alternative shapes in order to best understand how it interacts with the ACE2 receptor, so that an antibody can be designed. Low-resolution structures of the SARS-CoV spike protein exist and we know the mutations that differ between SARS-CoV and 2019-nCoV.  Given this information, we are uniquely positioned to help model the structure of the 2019-nCoV spike protein and identify sites that can be targeted by a therapeutic antibody. We can build computational models that accomplish this goal, but it takes a lot of computing power.   This is where you can contribute! With many computers working towards the same goal, we aim to help develop a therapeutic remedy as quickly as possible. Being part of Corona@Home, you can help provide us with the computational power required to tackle this problem. One protein from 2019-nCoV, a protease encoded by the viral RNA, has already been crystallized. Although the 2019-nCoV spike protein of interest has not yet been resolved bound to ACE2, our objective is to use the homologous structure of the SARS-CoV spike protein to identify therapeutic antibody targets.We can benefit from supercomputing power, scientific software framework and improved protein structure prediction using potentials from deep learning as a part of machine learning (see the section: DEEP LEARNING – IMPROVE PROTEIN STRUCTURE PREDICTION).COVID-19 research currently in developmentCorona@home is in contact with medical research organizations to provide them computing and deep learning power, to expedite the discovery and rollout of tests, treatments and cures.According to The Milken Institute, who created aggregation of publicly available information from validated sources, we track a comprehensive online tracker (https://milkeninstitute.org/sites/default/files/2020-03/Covid19%20Tracker%20032020v3-posting.pdf)  that looks at all of the COVID-19 research currently in development. Each row tracks a treatment or vaccine from discovery to clinical trial, accompanied by the name of the organization undertaking the research. This tool, collated from publicly available sources, will be updated regularly and we’ll contact listed institutions with a proposal of cooperation.This illustration, created at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), reveals ultrastructural morphology exhibited by coronaviruses. Note the spikes that adorn the outer surface of the virus, which impart the look of a corona surrounding the virion, when viewed electron microscopically. A novel coronavirus virus was identified as the cause of an outbreak of respiratory illness first detected in Wuhan, China in 2019. [Image and Caption Credit: Alissa Eckert, MS; Dan Higgins, MAM available at https://phil.cdc.gov/Details.aspx?pid=23311]Structures of the closely related SARS-CoV spike protein bound by therapeutic antibodies may help rapidly design better therapies. The three monomers of the SARS-CoV spike protein are shown in different shades of red; the antibody is depicted in green. [PDB: 6NB7 https://www.rcsb.org/structure/6nb7]
 
SCIENTIFIC BACKGROUNDThe essential component for many biological functions is protein. It takes actions in biological functions and participates in virtually all processes within biological cells. Commonly they behave like enzymes, carrying out biochemical reactions including cell signaling, cellular regulation and molecular transportation. Some act as a type of antibodies, others as a skeleton for cells and some proteins participate in the immune system. 
 
 
In the picture, we can see proteins on cancer cells, and joining it antibody. Source:https://d4j2i6ubvolvu.cloudfront.net/sites/defa...
First, before protein is allowed to take these roles, it must fold into a functional three-dimensional structure. This process is mostly spontaneous and depends on interaction within its amino acid sequence and interactions of the amino acids with their area.
Its very important to understanding how protein works and behave, and it is recognized as a holy grail of computational biology. Usually when in a crowded cellular environment folding is happening, the process passes smoothly. But, when due to a protein’s chemical characteristic or other factors, proteins can misfold. It means when protein fold down in the wrong way and end up deformed. If cellular mechanisms do not have the ability to refold misfolded proteins or destroy them, then they can aggregate and cause different diseases.
Because of complicatication of proteins conformation and also configuration space, and limits of computing power., stimulation of all-atom molecular dynamics have been very limited in the timescale.
Most proteins before 2010 mostly fold in the order of milliseconds, and simulation could only be done nanosecond to microsecond timescales. Power of supercomputers of usually have been used for simulating protein folding. But this operation was very expensive and mostly only shared among many research groups. Protein folding is not one step process. In some cases folding time of protein is nearly 96%, waiting in various intermediate conformational states, each a local thermodynamic free energy minimum in the protein’s energy landscape.
Folding@home is using conformations of a process known as adaptive sampling, and it is their starting point for a set of simulation trajectories. With every discovery of conformations made by simulations, trajectories are restarted from them and from this process is slowly created the Markov state model (MSM).
The length of the proteins that has studied Folding@home during 2000 and 2010 have increased by a factor of four, while its timescale of protein folding have increased by six orders of magnitude. Folding@home in 2002 started to use Markov state models to gather approximately a million CPU days of simulation over the span of a few months.
MSMs correlated another simulation in 2011 that required an aggregate of 10 million CPU hours of computing. Folding@home used MSMs in January 2010, to simulate the dynamics of the slow-folding 32-residue NTL9 protein out to 1.52 milliseconds, it was timescale compatible with experimental folding rate predictions. But it was a thousand times longer than achieved in the first place. Model was built with individual trajectories, each two orders of magnitude shorter, this was providing an unparalleled level of many details into the protein’s energy area.

WHAT IS PROTEIN FOLDING
Protein folding it is a physical process consisting of formation by a polypeptide (it owns a structure of random coil) highly organized structure with a characteristic and stable conformation.Each protein is assumed to be in the form of an unstructured polypeptide chain shortly after translation. Such a polypeptide does not show the presence of a well-defined, stable spatial structure. It is only due to the interaction between adjacent amino acids that the polypeptide begins to adopt a specific conformation, often referred to as the “native” state. It is currently believed that the main factor determining the native structure of a given protein is its amino acid sequence, however, some observations indicate that the natural structure of proteins found in a living cell may be dependent on interactions with other proteins or nucleic acids. 
Protein folding (schematic image). The macromolecular shape is changing from a chain-like structure (left) to the compact, characteristic native protein structure (right) while crossing complicated intermediate shapes. (Source: Article Structurally Resolved Coarse-Grained Modeling of Motor Protein Dynamics, Holger fleshsig; https://www.researchgate.net/publication/293317366_Structurally_Resolved_Coarse-Grained_Modeling_of_Motor_Protein_Dynamics) For most known proteins, the correct spatial structure is necessary for their physiological role. Failure to adopt the expected structure usually leads to the formation of a protein with different properties that can even be toxic to the body (an example can be many prion proteins). Much evidence suggests that certain neurodegenerative diseases are caused by the accumulation of proteins with abnormal structures such as amyloids that form long fibers in the cells.
References:
Berg JM, Tymoczko JL, Stryer L (2002). “3. Protein Structure and Function”. Biochemistry. San Francisco: W. H. Freeman. ISBN 978-0-7167-4684-3.
Dennis J. Selkoe. Folding proteins in fatal ways. „Nature”, s. 900–904, 2003. DOI: 10.1038/nature02264. PMID: 14685251.
Christian Anfinsen, The formation and stabilization of protein structure, „Biochemical Journal”, 128 (4), 1972, s. 737–49, PMID: 4565129, PMCID: PMC1173893.
The Shape and Structure of Proteins. W: Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, and Peter Walters: Molecular Biology of the Cell; Fourth Edition. Garland Science, 2002. ISBN 0-8153-3218-1.
 
EXAMPLES OF APPLICATION IN BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH
Protein misfolding can cause different diseases, for example Huntington’s disease, sickle-cell anemia, cancer, Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, Alzheimer’s disease and also type II diabetes. Virus HIV and also Influenza cause cellular infection are implay folding events on cell membranes. Understanding better protein misfolding, treatments can compound  that boost cells native ability to control protein folding. 
   
(Alzheimer’s disease is connected with  the aggregation of amyloid beta protein fragments in the brain (right). Researchers at the Folding@home used it to simulate this aggregation process, to better understand the cause of the disease.)  Such therapies include the use of engineered molecules to alter the production of a given protein, and help to destroy a misfolded protein, or assist in the folding process. The combination of computational molecular modeling and experimental analysis has the possibility to fundamentally shape the future of molecular medicine and the rational design of therapeutics. such as expediting and lowering the costs of drug discovery. For example, the first five years of work at Folding@home  was focused on progression in understanding folding, when now the goal is to understand misfolding and related disease, especially Alzheimer’s.  The simulations created by Folding@home are used in connection with experiments in the laboratory, but research workers   can use them to study how folding in vitro differs from folding in native cellular environments. Studying aspects of misfolding, folding and also correlations with diseases is really advantageous. For example, in 2011 Folding@home lead simulated protein folding inside a ribosomal exit which occurred to help researchers understand how natural confinement and crowding might influence the folding process.   Typically, scientists use a chemical compound – denatured alcoholin research to unfold proteins from their stable native state, but in general there  is no knowledge how it can affect the protein refolding. Folding@home in 2010 used GPUs to simulate the unfolded states of Protein L, and predicted its collapse rate in strong agreement with experimental results.  Non-profit unit – The Pande Lab which is part of Stanford University. Results of big data from projects are available for free. It can be used by other researchers upon request and also some of it can be obtained from Folding@home.  The collaborations between Blue Gene supercomputer, and Pande Lab and they ahre Folding@home key software with different research workers and various science centers. Thanks to that, algorithms which were useful for Folding@home, can be fruitful in other scientific areas.   The open-source Copernicus software, which they released in 2011 is based on Folding@home’s MSM and other parallelizing techniques and its target is to improve the efficiency and scaling of molecular simulations on large computer clusters or supercomputers. All summaries of every scientific discovery from Folding@home are available on Folding@home website.

HIDDEN MARKOV MODEL
 
Corona@home uses Markov state models, like the one diagrammed here, to model the possible shapes and folding pathways a protein can take as it condenses from its initial randomly coiled state (left) into its native 3-D structure (right).A protein before and after folding. It starts in an unstable random coil state and finishes in its native state conformation.  DEEP LEARNING – improve protein structure predictionmachine learning, artificial intelligence to improve protein structure prediction associated with COVID-19 Predicting the protein structure can be used to make a three-dimensional shape of a protein which is based on its amino acid sequence. This is the biggest dilmate for researchers, because the structure of protein in a big group regulate its function, but still structures of protein can be very hard to set experimentally. The last major progression of these studies has been achieved through the use of genetic information. We can predict which of the amino  acid remains are in interconnection. This can be reached by analyzing covariance in homologous sequences, which helps in predicting given protein structures.It gave us the chance to teach a neural network. Thanks to that, we have the ability to make accurate good forecasting of the distances between pairs of residues. This date includes much more information about structure than contact predictions. Applying this information, we have the ability to formulate a potential of power that can precisely portray the shape of a protein. This potential  we can form by a simple gradient descent algorithm to bring out structures without complex sampling procedures. By uncovering the prognosis of the structure of several poorly studied proteins related with  SARs-Cov_2- the virus that causes COVID-19, we can contribute to the development of science associated with this. We point, that these projections have not been scientifically confirmed. But we hope that they may do something for science associated with viruses functions and help with making hypothesis generation platform for future experimental work in developing therapeutics. For half a century  research workers had the ability to specify patterns of proteins in laboratories using magnetic resonance and X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy and also nuclear magnetic resonance. But error and trials  appear in each of these methods, and costs tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars per each protein structure and also it can take many years of research. That is why AI methods are chosen by biologists as a shorter path for  process for difficult proteins. They have two options. In the first they work on genetic code and thanks to this can predict the shape of the protein – faster and more reliable method. The second option available is to determine the protein with the help of long and costly experiments.How can AI make a difference?Thanks to rapid reduction in the cost of genetic sequencing the field of genomics is much more rich in data.The effect shows in deep  learning and it approaches the prediction problem that rely on genomic data have become increasingly successful in the last years. Biennial global competition called the Critical Assessment of Techniques for Protein Structure Prediction (CASP) was established in 1994. The CASP has been created to accumulate measure and research progress on the newest methods to accomplish better accuracy of predictions . In the center of interest for  AI teams is mainly the problem of modeling target shapes from zero, and without using previously solved proteins as patterns. AI teams  gained a high degree of precision, during predicting the physical properties of a protein structure, and then used two separate methods to create predictions of full protein structures. Using neural networks to predict physical propertiesDeep neural networks that are trained to predict properties of the protein form its genetic sequence – these two methods are based on this. The properties networks predict are: (a) the distances between pairs of amino acids and (b) the angles between chemical bonds that connect those amino acids. The first development is a progression of generally used techniques that estimate whether pairs of amino acids are near each other. A skilled neural network can predict a distribution of distances between every pair of residues in a protein (visualised in Figure 2). These probabilities were then combined into a score that estimates how accurate a proposed protein structure is. We can also train a single neural network that uses all distances in aggregate to estimate how close the proposed structure is to the right answer.FIGURE 2: Two ways of visualising the accuracy of prediction. The top figure features the distance matrices for three proteins. The brightness of each pixel represents the distance between the amino acids in the sequence comprising the protein – the brighter pixel, the closer the pair. Shown in the top row are the real, experimentally determined distances and, in the bottom row, the average predicted distances distributions. Importantly, these match well on both global and local scales. The bottom panels represent the same comparison using 3d models, featuring predictions (blue) versus ground-truth data (green) for the same three proteins. Because of the ability to use  these scoring functions, we can look for protein shape  and try to find structures that match our predictions. In the first method, which  is built on techniques usually used in structural biology, and repeatedly substituted parts of a protein structure with new protein fragments. Trained a generative neural network to invent novel  parts, which are used to incessantly develop the score of the proposed protein structure.FIGURE 3: A schematic of the architecture of the ALPHAFOLD system predicting structure from protein sequence.  The second method optimised scores through gradient descent—a mathematical technique mostly  used in machine learning for making small, incremental improvements—which appear in highly precise structures. This technique was applied to entire protein chains rather than to pieces that must be folded separately before being built up into a bigger structure, to simplify the prediction process.We are amazed  by the prosperity of the protein folding model, but still there is a lot of work before us in the realm of protein biology. We really want to find a way to establishing methods that AI can cooperate to fundamental scientific discovery.Because of that kind of thinking, it will lead us in the end to improve understanding about how it works and will be helpful for scientists to target and construct new, effective treatments for diseases in an improved way. Scientists have only mapped structures for about half of all the proteins made by human cells. There are a lot of rare diseases with mutation in a single gene, and this results in a malformed protein which can have  intense outcome on the health of an entire organism. This method probably has the ability to help us and reachers workers to find efficient drug discovery, and during this reducing the costs associated with experimentation. In our hearts, we hope that thanks to using AI for disease research could be useful and helpful to improve quality of life for millions of patients all over the globe. But advantages from it are not only restricted for health issues. Great knowledge about protein folding can also be of some use for instance  in advances in biodegradable enzymes – this can be done by protein design. This research could help us manage pollutants like oil and plastic, and support us in breaking down waste in ways that are more friendly to our earth. Some scientists have already begun engineering bacteria to single proteins that will make waste biodegradable and much more easier to process. Machine learning systems can integrate various sources of information about protein folding  – this significant data can help scientists come up with solutions to complex problems in a faster way. As we know how AI can help people master complex games through systems like AlphaGo and AlphaZero, We think AI breakthroughs will help serve as a platform to advance our knowledge of essential, scientific dilemmas in a much quicker way. It is very interesting and exciting to be witness  to these signs of progress in protein folding, improving the utility of AI for scientific discovery. There is still numerous work and a lot of  research to do before we are able to have a significant effect on treating diseases, managing waste, and more and more… and we know the potential of it is  tremendous.

Corona@home’s DEV and system architecture
 
Corona@home system involves five components: work units, core, server/grid of the masternodes, client/wallet and tools (client for mobile phones and nextgen video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft planned in the future)Work unitsA work unit is the protein data that the client is asked to process. Work units are a fraction of the simulation between the states in a Markov state model. After the work unit has been downloaded and fully processed by a users computer, it is returned to Corona@home servers, which then award the user with  credit points and this cycle is automatic. All work units have linked deadlines, and if this deadline is exceeded, the user may not get credit and the unit will be automatically reissued to another participant. As protein folding occurs serially, and many work units are generated from their predecessors, this gives  the overall simulation process to proceed in a normal way if a work unit is not returned after a sensible period of time. Because of these deadlines  the minimum system demand for Corona@home is a Pentium 3 450 MHz CPU with Streaming SIMD Extensions (SSE). Major advantage of the scientific benefit is dependent on rapidly competing simulations that’s why work units for high-performance clients have a  much shorter deadline than those for the uniprocessor client.Before public release, work units go through several quality assurance steps to keep problematic ones from becoming fully available. These testing stages include internal, beta, and advanced, before a final full release across Corona@home. Work units from Corona@home’s are typically processed only once, except in the uncommon event that errors occur during processing. If this occurs for three different users, the unit is automatically pulled from distribution.The Corona@home support forum can be used to differentiate between issues arising from problematic hardware and bad work units.CoreThe calculations on the work unit are made by specialized molecular dynamics programs as a background process.  Major amount of Corona@home’s cores are lean on GROMACS(GROningen MAchine for Chemical Simulations). It is one of the powerful and most popular molecular dynamics software packages, which mostly rely on manually optimized assembly language code and hardware optimizations.To enable the scientific methods to be updated automatically without requiring a client update the core is separated from the clienti. When work of cores is interrupted can resume work from  point upon startup that is why cores periodically create calculation checkpoints. GROMACS is a comprehensive package to perform molecular dynamics, i.e. simulate the Newtonian equations of motion for systems with hundreds to millions of particles.It is  mostly designed for biochemical molecules like proteins, lipids and nucleic acids that have a lot of complicated bonded interactions, but since GROMACS is very fast at calculating the nonbonded interactions many groups are also using it for research on non-biological systems, e.g. polymers.GROMACS assists  all the standard algorithms you expect from modern molecular dynamics implementation.  In the code a lot of algorithmic optimizations have been introduced. For example, extract the calculation of the virial from the innermost loops over pairwise interactions, and they use their own software routines to calculate the inverse square root.In GROMACS 4.6 and up, on almost all common computing platforms, the innermost loops are written in C using inner  functions that the compiler transforms to SIMD machine instructions, to utilize the accessible instruction-level parallelism. These kernels are available in  single and also double precision, and assist all the different kinds of SIMD support found in x86-family processors.http://www.gromacs.orgClient/WalletUsers of Corona@home install a client/wallet program on their  personal computer (mobile devices and next gen game consoles – future roadmap). Participant collaborate with the client, which manages other software or masternodes components in the background.Throughout the client/wallet, the user may stop and pause the folding process, open an event log, and check work development  or also view personal statistics. Computers of clients run uninterruptedly in the background at a low priority, by using idle processing power and because of that clients computer normal work is unaffected. The maximum CPU use can be adjusted via client settings.The client connects to a Corona@home server and retrieves a work unit and may also download the appropriate core for the client’s settings, operating system, and the underlying hardware architecture. After processing, the work unit is returned to the Corona@home servers. Computer clients are conformable to uniprocessors and multi-core processor systems, and also graphics processing units. The diversity and power of each hardware architecture provides Corona@home with the ability to successfully complete many types of simulations in a timely manner (in a few weeks or months rather than years), which is of significant scientific value. Together, these clients allow researchers to study biomedical questions formerly considered impractical to tackle computationally.Professional software developers are responsible for Corona@home’s code, both for the client and server-side.  While the client’s graphical user interface (GUI) is open-source, the client is proprietary software citing security and scientific integrity as the reasons. CLIENT/WALLET FOR MOBILE PHONES ( ROADMAP Q3 2020)1. Monitor the progress and status of your folding slots while not being near your systems. It will also enable you to change settings of the configuration of your folding systems or visualize proteins in 3D on your computer or servers which they work on.2. Due to the progressively increasing performance of top smartphones (e.g based on Snapdragon 865 with Adreno 650 GPU or Apple A13 Bionic with A13 Bionic’s GPU), we plan to include Android and iOS apps and implement mobile devices in the Corona@home’s distributed computing ecosystem.SERVER / MASTERNODEMasternodes serve as the integrity of Corona@home’s blockchain ecosystem, stakeable CORO passive income and a grid of distributed supercomputers to simulate and predict the dynamics of proteins.For volunteering and network grid using API, an open-source middleware system  is anticipated – Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing (BOINC).At first it was used to support the SETI@home, but this platform became resultful in a novel and inventive way for other applications in  various fields of science like mathematics, medicine, molecular biology, climatology, astrophysics, linguistics. The target of BOINC is to provide researchers to step into the enormous processing resources of multiple personal computers around the world.Scientific computations are run on users’ computers. After sending the user from the client to the scientific researchers database, the backend server checks and analyzes the results. The validation process engage  running all tasks on computers with multiple collaborators and comparing results.  BOINC provides APIs for various types of applications and web sites that interact with BOINC components:
Client GUIs: Applications that control local or remote BOINC clients.
Credit statistics web sites: Web sites showing credit information (project totals, user/team/country leaderboards) based on daily XML feeds of statistics data from BOINC projects. The XML format is documented here.
Account managers: Web sites that let BOINC users create and manage accounts on multiple projects.
Aggregate credit statistics: Web RPCs for getting cross-project credit data for hosts, teams and users.
Web RPCs: These interfaces let a program or web site obtain information about projects, and create/edit entities (users, teams, hosts) on projects.
Local editing of preferences: This mechanism lets you write programs for local editing of preferences.
APIs for remote job submission, management of input files, and fetching output files.
https://boinc.berkeley.eduTOOLSBiopython – set of tools for biological computation written in Python by an international team of developersTensorFlow – machine learning models for desktop, mobile, web, and cloud. Open Neural Network Exchange(ONNX) – open standard for machine learning interoperabilityUniclust – Databases of clustered and deeply annotated protein sequences and alignmentsHHpred web server – Bioinformatics ToolkitCATH – database, online resource that provides information on the evolutionary relationships of protein domainsPDB – Protein Data Bank archive, repository of information about the 3D structures of proteins, nucleic acids, and complex assemblies.SST (web server): Secondary STructure assignment to protein coordinate data using the Bayesian method of Minimum Message Length inferenceTM-align – an algorithm for sequence independent protein structure comparisons. For two protein structures of unknown equivalence, TM-align first generates optimized residue-to-residue alignment based on structural similarity using heuristic dynamic programming iterationsMicrosoft Cognitive Toolkit – deep learning frameworkCMView – Protein contact map visualization and analysis with PyMOL molecular visualization system Roadmap Q1.2020Research & DevelopmentMainnet PreparationLaunch public testnet V1.0Preparation of the CORO technical supportOpen mainnet masternode featureCORO Network Mainnet releaseDesktop wallets for Windows, Linux and OSX Q2.2020Proof of conceptUpdate of CORO's purchase portfolioMoves to public repositoryDeep learning algorithms with masternodes integrationBlockchain wallets for distributed computing integrationTools and core implementation to performing molecular dynamics simulationsComputing power available for scientific institutions and researches Q3.2020Computing & researchesBOINC client/server and API integrationCPU and GPU accelerated computing for scientific institutions and researchesMobile apps development (control folding server and mobile wallets)On-line wallet (an option)CORO debut on selected crypto exchanges Q4.2020Productivity expansionEnergy efficiency and productivity for precise targeted AI projectsLaunch CORO white label trading platform with major currency pairsLedger hardware wallet integrationClient development for Sony Playstation 5 and Microsoft XBOX Series X 2021Global market expansionCentre for Distributed and Global Computing Projects  ExecutiveTeamMeet the people behind 


Daniel Możdżyński
Project Manager,Co-founder

He completed PhD studies at the Faculty of Informatics and e-Economy, Department of Information Technology at the Poznan University of Economics and Business and post-graduate studies - "IT Project Management". He is a graduate of the MBA at the WSB University in Poznan in cooperation with the Franklin University in Ohio. He gained professional experience and expert knowledge in such companies as HP, Fujitsu-Siemens, General Electric and at leading integrators of ICT solutions. He belongs to the Agile Alliance and PMI (Project Management Institute), where he has the status of a member. The author of academic publications, agile coach, mentor, lecturer and an experienced project practitioner
 




Tomasz Węgliński

Developer, Co-founderFull Stack Blockchain Developer. Highly professional blockchain developer with 15 years of experience, solid leadership skills, and unrivalled building skills. Experienced in languages such as Python, Perl, C/C++, PowerShell. Data Science skills - Python, R and Data Analytics/Machine Learning skills
 




Krzysztof Wójcicki

Research Institutions and Labs Cooperation ManagerPhD in the field of Commodity Science, from PUEB. He works at the Department of Technology and Instrumental Analysis at the Institute of Quality Science, PUEB. His work center around the novel methods for quality evaluation of various food and non-food products. He is particularly interested in the field of spectroscopy and multivariate data analysis.
 




Elżbieta Wanowska

ConsultantMSc in Molecular Biology, PhD student in Biotechnology, Adam Mickiewicz University Poznan Faculty of Biology
 




Magda Krzciuk
Administrative Specialist, Customer ServiceShe provides administrative and customer support to the Corona@home. She has experience providing administrative support in both corporate and non-profit settings. Her fields of interest are financial market and foreign-exchange market, which is her job for almost four years. She also actively participates in cryptocurrency market

story:
Citrus is a patented doorknob sanitizer that safely harnesses the power of UV light to eliminate 99.9% of pathogens on door knobs — helping prevent the spread of germs.

 

 

Germs are everywhere... especially on doorknobs and levers.

The Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommends regular disinfection of doorknobs and levers in residences, schools, office spaces, hospitals, nursing homes, cruise ships, and more to help mitigate the spread of germs. 

  • https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/disinfecting-your-home.html

  • https://www.cdc.gov/flu/resource-center/images/multi-language-pdfs/contamination_cleaning_english_508.pdf

  • https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/disinfecting-building-facility.html

Citrus provides a solution to a problem that is ubiquitous in today’s world.

 

 

Citrus is easy to install! No tools required. 

 

 

HOW IT WORKS

  1. Citrus detects movement of the door
  2. Citrus enters into a delay of 10 seconds
  3. Citrus activates the UV-C Lights for 60 seconds
  4. After sanitization process is complete Citrus enters into standby mode ready for the next time the door is used

 

 

Today, UV-C light is used in countless applications in order to purify the air we breathe, the water we drink, and the surfaces we touch. UV-C light is an increasingly prevalent and efficient sanitation method. 

 

Currently available in three different door knob finishes.

 

 

 

Citrus disinfects doorknob surfaces by emitting ultraviolet light at the “germicidal” wavelength of 270-285nm. This wavelength is within the ultraviolet-C band (UV-C) which has been scientifically proven to kill or inactivate microorganisms (viruses, bacteria, fungi, etc.) by destroying their nucleic acids and disrupting their DNA.

 

 

In 2017, Citrus was just an idea casually tossed around at the gym. Since that initial discussion, Citrus has evolved into a fully functioning tested prototype, and now ready to be used in homes.

Efficacy tests for the first revision of Citrus’ were conducted in 2018 at the Center for Innovative Ventures of Emerging Technologies Department of Biomedical Engineering Rutgers Medical Device Development Center using a 12mW LED UV-C light. Three common pathogens were tested: Escherichia coli (E.coli), Pseudomonas Aeruginosa (PA), and Staphylococcus Aureus (SA). Timing intervals used were 15 seconds.

The reduction of pathogens using UV-C lights are a result of three main factors: Radiant Flux (power of the UV-C light), distance, and time.

 

Ee=Φe/(4πd^2 )

 

Citrus’ first revision test results surpassed theoretically calculated reduction values showing a 99% reduction of E. Coli in 15 seconds, Staph. Aureus in 45 seconds, and Pseudomonas Aeruginosa in 90 seconds. Since then Citrus has incorporated a stronger LED UV-C, 19mW (58% stronger) and is mounted closer to the doorknob (1.5 inches at the furthest point vs. 2.5 inches in the first revision).

These changes have made this current version of Citrus 439% more effective, in other words, 4.39 times quicker at killing pathogens than the first version tested at the Center for Innovative Ventures of Emerging Technologies.

 

SUSTAINABILITY

 

From how we operate within our company to how we partner with our customers and communities, sustainability is a key value of our business. 

Currently, Citrus' packaging is 100% recyclable material and the LED UVC lights last, on average, 10,000 hours. For a household of four that will last longer than 5 years.

We see tremendous opportunity, in the near future, to expand the use of reusable/rechargeable batteries, recyclable and recycled materials for packaging, and various other product elements to meet today's environmental best practice standards.

As we look to the future, we are committed to causing no unnecessary harm and using our business to inspire environmental stewardship and healthy/safe solutions to drive our community forward.

 

Keep Up with Citrus on Social Media

 

Hit the buttons below to stay updated on our journey and to share our page with a friend or family member who you know would love Citrus.
